Settlement.text: {=!}Druchii Slaver Camp

Settlement.name: {=!}Hunger Woods
Settlement.text: {=!}Called Verhungern by local Slyvanians, this dispersed land is a ghoul, and likely spirit, infested maze of briars and bogs. Only the insane or desperate would venture into its boughs.

Settlement.name: {=!}Hel Fenn
Settlement.text: {=!}Destroyed by unholy fire that rained from the skies eons ago, Hel Fenn is likely the most cursed area in the whole Reik Basin. Molded buildings, rotting trees and tar covered corpses dot the desolate landscape. This was also the site of Mannfred von Carsteins defeat and the end of the Vampire Wars.

Settlement.name: {=!}The Barren Hills
Settlement.text: {=!}Long have the hills southeast of Talabheim been cursed. Strangeness and tragedy are no stranger to that land. Despite this, no one knows what the cause of the miasma is; though not for lack of trying.

Settlement.name: {=!}The Charnel Hills
Settlement.text: {=!}Centuries ago, the hills outside of Mousillon were used as a mass grave to bury the thousands who died of Red Pox. So many victims were there that to this day the soil covering their pits is visible from the city walls. The air here is sometimes poisonous and like the rest of the cursed land the long dead rest uneasily.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_AV1}Averheim
Settlement.text: {=!}Averheim, the capital of the Grand Province of Averland, is one of the oldest cities in the Empire. The site upon which the modern city now lies has been occupied since before the time of Sigmar when the Averlanders were still called Brigrundians. The dockyards here are particularly bustling due to the Aver serving as the primary trade route for the Halfling goods from the Moot into the wider empire. The bluff that the city sits upon protects the inhabitants from occasional flooding and has always served as an ideal crossing point across the Aver River; making the Griffin bridge one of the only places for many miles which provides access across the river for merchants and travellers heading north into Stirland or south into Averland. The skyline of the city is dominated by the Averburg Palace, a formidable fortress originally built around the founding of the Empire; views of the surrounding lands from the palace go for several miles all around the city. The city is famous for its cattle stockyards, the final destination of thousands of Averland cattle, the Plenzerplatz and of course its lord; Marious Lietdorf, the mad count of Averland.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_AV1_1}Streissen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_AV1_1}Located just down river from the confluence of the rivers Aver and Lammer, the town of Streissen is known for its revolutionary spirit and volatile past. The town hosts a small university and medical school, infamous for producing pupils who do not abide by the old ways. Streissen once held its own town charter, granting many tax exemptions and the ability to elect its own leaders, but this was revoked in a deal with the Countess Ludmilla Alptraum who saved the town from a student-led revolution. The university continues to operate with the memory of the purge following the Alptraum’s violent suppression still fresh in most residents’ minds. A ferry providing access across the Aver operates here.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_AV1_2}Lengenfeld
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_AV1_2}Lengenfeld serves as the primary holding of Countess Carmilla von Sachs. The people here fish the river Aver for sustenance, drying and trading the rest along with their cattle to create wealth. A ferry here is also maintained to facilitate travel and trade across the Aver, a tax is collected for their lord.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_AV1_3}Bieswang
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_AV1_3}On the western border of the Wailing Woods is the village of Bieswang. The people here survive off of what they can grow and trade to purchase what they cannot. Unlike most Averlanders, their proximity to a supposedly cursed wood has made the lot of them superstitious; newcomers may be hard pressed to earn their trust.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_AV1_4}Heideck
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_AV1_4}Sat on the crossroads of the Old Dwarf Road, the town of Heideck was originally constructed by the Dwarfs during the height of their kingdoms several millennia ago. The few still-standing dwarf structures remain in use by the humans here, a living testament to the architectural standards of the elder race. Below Heideck is rumoured to be many dwarf catacombs, filled with ancient treasure and artefacts just waiting to be unsealed and taken.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_AV2}Wuppertal
Settlement.text: Wuppertal is a picturesque Averlandish town, some might even say frozen in its cherished past. The city is known for carpentry, fine beer and ale (by human standards) and its tradition abiding Averlander inhabitants. The town also hosts many pilgrims and zealots, serving as one of the southern strongholds for the cult of Sigmar whose shrine here is dedicated to Joseph the Reverent. The town also hosts a large temple of Verena and a Garden of Morr. As with many settlements along the Upper Reik, a ferry operates to bring goods and people across the river into Averland or out to Wissenland.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_AV2_1}Colmfӓhre
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_AV2_1}Surrounded by a ditch and a stone palisade is the town of Colmfӓhre. This is a modest town and is ruled by Baron Sigmund Hindenberg, who maintains his vigil over the settlement and the surrounding area from Castle Hindenburg, situated on a nearby hill. A ferry serves travellers seeking to cross the Reik river, heading south into Wissenland or north into Averland.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_AV2_2}Loningbruck
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_AV2_2}As a small town in southern Averland, Loningbruck serves as a crucial stop for merchants travelling along the Reik, either downriver towards Marienburg and the Great Ocean or upriver to the Dwarfen Kingdoms. One of the only roads leading to and from the Blackfire Pass also passes through Loningbruck. As a result of these mercantile interests, the town’s economy relies on the trade these routes bring, supplemented only by the sale of cattle. The town is dominated by The Crossed Keys, a large coaching inn, and the temple of Verena, the largest temple in town. Loningbruck unfortunatly also lends its name to Loningbruck Ruby, a infamously low-quality type of wine.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_AV2_3}Bernloch
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_AV2_3}Home to the Baroness Alder, the unassuming village of Bernloch is most famous for its Bernloch Hard Cheese. The people here mostly raise goats for both their meat and their cheese, as well as facilitate trade along the Agbeiten-Heideck Road.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_AV3}Grenzstadt
Settlement.text: {=!}The fortress town of Grenzstadt guards the approaches to and from the infamous Black Fire Pass. The Old Dwarf Road also passes through it on its northern route. As a result of its geography the town is in the perfect position to both facilitate trade with the Dwarfen Karaks and to guard against invasion by Greenskins and similar ilk coming through the Black Fire Pass. Tall and formidable walls and towers, and the size of its merchant quarter, enlarge the true size of the town. On any given day there are typically more visitors in the town than permanent inhabitants. Of these inhabitants, 1/10th of them are Dwarfs, here to serve as agents for their clans and to watch for human thieves seeking to sell stolen dwarf artefacts in the Empire. It is also known for Grenzstadter wine, high quality wine known for causing little to no hangover effects.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_AV3_1}Hochsleben
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_AV3_1}The docks here at Hochsleben mark the end of the Upper Reik for boat traffic. While the river continues higher into the mountains for many miles, past this point the rapids, falls and ascent becomes far too dangerous for travel. As a result the town typically hosts a number of boats and ships, all plying their trade in goods going to or coming from the World’s edge mountains.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_AV3_2}Agbeiten
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_AV3_2}Agbeiten is a large village that serves as both a mercantile and religious hub in Southern Averland. The Taalebenplatz, the centre of Agbeiten, is a large square where Agbeiten holds its daily market located at the crossroads of the Loningbruck-Hochsleben and Heideck Roads. On the northern end of the square are shrines to Sigmar, Ulric, and Verena. The round, timberbuilt Temple of Taal and Rhya is one of the largest in the Southern Empire and one of the few located within the stone walls of a town. The people of Agbeiten are mostly followers of Taal and Rhya.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_AV4}Pfungzig
Settlement.text: On the eastern border of Averland stands Pfungzig, a fortress and seat of power belonging to von Heine. Pfungzig commands a view of many miles around it, allowing one to watch over a large stretch of the Blue Reach, the southern Wailing Woods and Southern Stirland. While no bridge stands here to cross the nearby river, the fortress maintains a ferry for those with crowns who wish to cross.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_AV4_1}Zell
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_AV4_1}The small village of Zell was founded on one of the feeding tributaries of the Blue Reach. While the water here is too shallow for larger trading vessels, which are common to other rivers, the villagers use small boats and rafts to transport their crops to Fallenblatt, where it can be sold to the Halflings or transported further down river.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_AV4_2}Dietfurts
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_AV4_2}Dietfurts supplies grain to the surrounding settlements as well as for the stores in Pfunzig. The villagers here are suspicious of newcomers, fearing they are halfing spies or worse; travellers from eastern Stirland. Count von Heine hires many of his troops from Dietfurts, many of whom return home when they retire, as a result the men of Dietfurts make for excellent soldiers.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_ST1}Wurtbad
Settlement.text: {=!}Wurtbad rests on the banks of the river Stir and it´s the capital of the province. By far the most densely populated town in Stirland, it is also home to the crumbling Temple of Myrmida. The nobility and people of Wurtbad are famous for its suspiciousness and sombreness, as the lost province of Sylvania is too close for comfort. It is one of the few places where goods can be carried over the river, making it an excellent strategic checkpoint for anyone wishing to push onwards into the land.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ST1_1}Biberhof
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ST1_1}Biberhof lies surrounded by thick forest just a few kilometers south of Wurtbad. Its inhabitants have become quite skilled in the use of the axe, both to harvest high quality wood from the old trees around it and defending their camps from vermin and the occasional highwayman. The timber from Biderhof is sought after by the nobility of Wurtbad, as it is said its dark hues is anathema to any vampire unlucky enough to be skewed by a stake made from this wood.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ST1_2}Julbach
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ST1_2}Julbach is located halfway between River Stir and River Aver. It sits in a valley shadowed by the Zaya hills where sheep roam freely along Nuln road. The Nattern Forest, a few miles to the West, serves as both a source of wealth and superstition, as even in the coldest nights of winter, when both insect and beast sleep, a rumble of hooves can be heard in the distance.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ST1_3}Oberwil
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ST1_3}Oberwil is a small fishing village a few miles West of Wurtbad. The routes to Oberwil are little more than footpaths, as most trade and travel is done via river. The village is somewhat protected by the Riverwardens who frequent the Stir, but villagers generally have to fend for themselves against bandits and beastmen from the dark forest.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ST1_4}Tarshof
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ST1_4}Tarshof is situated on the Northern edge of the Stirhügel hills. The village enjoys plenty of traffic from traders travelling between Wurtbad and Wörden along the Old Dwarf Road. As a result almost every house in the village professes to be an Inn, although the hospitality varies wildly and travellers are as likely to find themselves sleeping on a pile of hay as a proper pallet bed.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_ST1}Flensburg
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_ST1}Flensburg is a small market town nestled in the Zaya Hills to the West of the Stirhügel. The hills are perfect for sheep grazing, and the town’s economy is based on fleece, lamb and mutton. The town is also noted in the region for having a major temple of Shallya.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ST1_1}Lochen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ST1_1}Lochen is a subsidiary settlement of the nearby town Flensburg. The village mostly consists of farmers who supply the market town with grain. Lochen falls under the protection of Countess Petra Harden and her troops.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_ST2}Franzen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_ST2}Franzen is a somewhat unremarkable town, sitting in the shadow of large settlements nearby. It has a healthy fishing trade from the Lammer and the Aver, and also boasts a well-used ferry across the Lammer which allows travellers to continue the road West to Russbach.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ST2_1}Chrobok
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ST2_1}Chrobok is a small farming community situated in the low wetlands between the rivers Mattid, Lammer and Aver. The natural irrigation provided by the rivers has made the region perfect arable land, and the nearby Franzen and Averheim enjoy a bountiful supply of grain from the village.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ST2_2}Russbach
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ST2_2}Russbach is a hamlet situated in the sodden fens to the South of the Stirhügel hills. Just beneath the surface of the earth are deep clay pits, and the people of Russbach make a living by mining the building material. Travellers know they’re near the village when they can smell the acrid smoke of the brickmakers’ kilns.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_ST3}Halstedt
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_ST3}Halstedt Keep is on the South-East edge of the Stirhügel hills and is a staging point for the Roadwardens of the region. Originally it was a manor house belonging to some long forgotten lord, over time it has become more fortified as each subsequent owner has sought to protect its inhabitants against bandits and the greenskins from nearby Altern Forest. Eventually it fell into state hands, and was turned into a fortress lodge for the official Roadwardens who protect the locale.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ST3_1}Raab
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ST3_1}Raab is a village which formed naturally around a Shallyan Shrine. Situated at the confluence of many roads, it was a natural place for a roadside shrine - a place for travellers to stop, rest and ask for blessings on their journey. One day a wine merchant who frequented the shrine realised the value of such easy custom, and built an Inn at the crossroads. It wasn’t long until a community had built up around it, and the village of Raab was formed.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ST3_2}Tenneck
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ST3_2}Tenneck is a village of vintners who supply the local Roadwarden stronghold at Halstedt Keep. Tennech formed from the families of bondmen who tended to the grounds and nobles living at Halstedt Manor. When Halstedt Manor was turned into Halstedt Keep, they were made into freemen, and decided to cultivate their land for selling fruit and drink. The Roadwardens of Halstedt Keep often accept a few gallons of wine a month in exchange for keeping the people of Tenneck safe.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_ST2}Leicheberg
Settlement.text: {=!}Amongst the Haunted Hills by the source of the Black Run River, lies the small town of Leicheberg. The people here live in constant fear of its neighbour to the east, Sylvania. Its ruler, Count Petr von Stolpe, has faced the Undead many times in his life and takes many measures to prepare for their return. Many witch hunters and vampire hunters have taken up residence here as a result. The town is notable for hosting a far larger temple and Garden of Morr than the number of inhabitants would otherwise require, for Count von Stolpe feels it is his obligation to ensure proper burials for all who die in his demesne.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ST2_1}Swartzhafen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ST2_1}Swartzhafen is a small village notable for its history. A great battle was fought here almost five hundred years prior, the ruins of a castle and the old village to the east of the settlement purportedly all that physically remains of that conflict. The modern village is prosperous, but wary of outsiders due to its situation near Sylvania.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ST2_2}Naubonum
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ST2_2}Naubonum is a small village right on the border of Sylvania. The people here get by mostly by raising crops to feed themselves, with any other goods purchased through the sale of excess crops or labour. Situated near the Haunted Hills, the inhabitants are often worried about outsiders from the east, Spectres and foul creatures. The Halfling Fieldwardens are known to stop in the settlement from time to time while patrolling the eastern reaches of the Moot.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ST2_3}Bylorhof
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ST2_3}The small town of Bylorhof has recently reentered the fold of the holy after throwing off their Sylvanian overlords. The cult of Bylorak, God of the marshes west of town, is the predominant belief of the inhabitants and Bylorak’s priests have taken charge of the town and its affairs, seeking greater support and reintegration with Stirland. There are four small temples in the town dedicated to Bylorak, Morr, Sigmar and Shallya respectively. The old lords castle lies in ruins to the west of town, right next to the Bylorhof Marshes.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_ST3}Siegfriedhof
Settlement.text: {=!}On the border of traditional Sylvania lies the town of Siegfriedhof. Nestled between the Hunger Wood’s fringes and the Svarsee, it has historically commanded a strategic position in the Eschenstir basin. The town is overseen by the High and Chivalric Order of Deserved Rest, better known as the Raven Knights, whose Grandmaster personally sees to the protection of the people here. Stewardship over Siegfriedhof was granted to the Morrian templars by the Elector Count of Stirland, in gratitude for the Order's contribution in the Battle of Hel Fenn, 400 years prior. The town is also the site of the Abbey of Blessed Aethelbert the Vigilant. Due to the significant cult presence of the Morrians, Siegfriedhof is often used as a staging area for agents to keep watch over Sylvania. The people of Siegfriedhof are quite suspicious of strangers, and preemptive lynchings of unknown travellers have been known to occur.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ST3_1}Sterniste
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ST3_1}A prosperous forest village situated between the Hunger Wood and the Svarsee, the people here at Sterniste make most of their wealth from cutting the local timber and floating it up the Eschenstir to Siegfriedof for market. The people here are very devoted to Morr, having often called upon the Raven Knights to defend them from Goblins and other dangers of the nearby woods or threats from even farther afield.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ST3_2}Vierstein
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ST3_2}Vierstein is a small village situated on the southern side of the marshy Morfens, within the Eschenstir basin. The people here are highly isolated from the outside world, only interacting with the wider Empire when they make their voyages to Siegfriedhof to sell their dried fish. The Viersteiners are also known for being excellent marksmen, often serving as bowmen or scouts for the Raven Knights.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_ST4}Mittlenburg
Settlement.text: {=!}Mittlenburg sits at the foot of the black mountains, not far from the fallen Karak Varn and lake Black Water. The town is a modest one, the people here are very aware of their precarious position between Black Fire Pass and Sylvania, as such the town is decently fortified in preparation for these threats. The temples of Sigmar and Taal are well consecrated, and the Garden of Morr has a protective curtain wall around it. Many pilgrims on their way to take the trek up to the final temple of Skaranorak stop in Mittlenburg to purchase supplies. Special Scenes: no special scenes, besides maybe the temples, would be nice if one of the temples of Skaranorak was visible from a vantage point somewhere in the town.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ST4_1}Kaunitz
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ST4_1}Kaunitz is a small hamlet in the far south of Stirland. The people here make most of their living out of cultivating the hilly land surrounding their town, supplemented with what ore they can scrape out of the earth. Most travellers and their goods are welcomed in Kaunitz and Dwarfs often pass through here on their travels out of the mountains and into the wider Empire. However the people are wary of queer folk and will not hesitate to run a Strigany camp or other such rubbish out of their home.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ST4_2}Marburg
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ST4_2}Marburg is a small village on the road between Wurtbad and Siegfreidhof. The village is known for its swine and crops which can help feed many of the nearby communities and towns following a good harvest. Unfortunately the village’s proximity to the Great Forest means frequent incursions by its denizens, and subsequently poorer harvests.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_ST4_3}Sigmaringen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_ST4_3}Sigmaringen is the first of seven temples to Sigmar which follows the original path taken by the first emperor into the black mountains to slay Sharanorak, a first-born Dragon Ogre. The people here make most of their money hosting the pilgrims and supplying them with food and equipment for their trek up into the mountains.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_ST4}Wördern
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ST4_1}Wördern is a small town hidden between mountains and valleys. The rough terrain makes expansion near impossible, but the intersection of the Old Dwarf Road and the Prager strasse makes passing along viable; not that it matters, as no outsider finds kindness in Wörden. The odd mootlander can occasionally be seen purchasing supplies for the road, but its main attraction is the Wörden Meat and Cattle auction house. It’s the only town in Stirland that can be smelled before it is seen.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ST4_1}Nussbach
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ST4_1}Nussbach is a small hamlet at the fork of River Lammer, where its two sources meet. The fertile flats at its south are the perfect spot to raise cattle, which Nussbachers have been doing for generations. The peaceful village is only bothered from time to time with land disputes from upstart Averland nobles.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ST4_2}Kelham
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_ST4_2}Kelham is isolated among the hills of the Old Dwarf Road. Its secluded location allows the inhabitants to peacefully farm wheat and other cereals. Its golden fields go just about the start of Altern Forest, where the fertility of the land drops inexplicably. Whatever is not used for local consumption is sent out along the Moot Road to the rest of eastern Stirland and, ultimately, the Mootlands.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_ST5}Marberg
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_ST5}Marberg Castle lies to the south of Mittlenburg near the pilgrim trail leading to the seven temples of Sharanorak. The castle was erected to safeguard the passes leading out of the World’s Edge mountains for Dwarf traders as well as to watch over the territory north of the Black Fire Pass.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_MT1}Eicheschatten
Settlement.text: {=!}Home of the Halflings and the Elder of the Mootland, which is the title preferred by Halflings as “Grand Count” sounds “too posh,” Eicheschatten is a collection of winding lanes along the banks of the Aver Reach at the end of the road from Wördern and Halstedt.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_MT1_1}Gipfel
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_MT1_1}Gipfel, A small village in the heart of the Greenleaf Hills.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_SY1}Castle Drakenhof
Settlement.text: {=!}The former Imperial capital of Sylvania has endured much upheaval through the ages. Formerly the home of the Imperial Elector Count Otto von Drak. After the establishment of the Von Carstein bloodline it became the seat of vampiric power in the Old World. Stained with the blood of all Von Carstein patriarchs who fought to become the castle’s next ruler. It is where Manfred Von Carstein resides. It is a dark lair to the terrible and occult. Adventurers often raid the castle seeking to plunder it’s secrets. Most meet a gruesome end within it’s cursed halls.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_SY1_1}Drakenhof
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_SY1_1}The town of Drakenhof was once considered a beacon of culture within the Empire. But after the sinister takeover of Sylvania by the Vampire Counts, the formerly tall and inspiring spires of Castle Drakenhof now loom menacingly over the townspeople of Drakenhof. The people of Drakenhof are oppressed under the thumb of the Von Carstein lineage. They use the town of Drakenhof to hide their dangerous and other worldly possessions. The people exist as snacks for passing vampires. And every dark corner is the lair for myraid and unspeakable evils. Praying on the townsfolk from dusk till dawn.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_SY1_2}Nachthafen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_SY1_2}Nachthafen is a very uninteresting place. Which is just as it’s ruler Countess Gabriella von Bundebad prefers. Nachthafen does not get involved in the petty squabbles of vampiric intrigue. Nor does it seek war with the Empire. It exists purely as a quiet, normal village. With nothing to see here. Just tasty villagers minding their business until it is time for the masters to feed.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_SY1_3}Folburg
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_SY1_3}Folburg was the site of a minor rebellion by mortal villagers against their vampiric overlord. Despite gruesomely ripping apart Count Aduhl von Kohnfried with his dying breath he left a curse. The flesh of the villagers began slowly rotting away. But their lives would not leave this mortal coil. The villagers found themselves eternal slaves to a dead master. Now they are maddened skeletons roaming their old dwellings. Pretending to a cheap parody of life. And you better not remind them of what they are.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_SY1_4}Gerhof
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_SY1_4}Gerhof does not sleep. It’s paranoid vampire Count Johan von Goal has forbidden it. A trickster Crone allegedly put a curse on the count. But none other than the Count himself can verify this. It has been said that a sleeping mortal would slay von Goal in a brutal fashion. So von Goal banned sleep. The mortal citizens are skittish. Sneaking an hour or two’s nap in the dark corners of the city. Ordered to be ever watchful for the one who would slay their fearful ruler.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_SY1}Castle Templehof
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_SY1}There are tales of Castle Templehof. At one point in history it was the home of the cruel Countess Emanuelle von Templehof. During a dark and terrible battle with the Dwarfs besieging her home Countess Emanuelle bathed her castle in profane magic. Causing an everlasting night to envelop the surrounding area. The indomitable Dwarfs persisted however. Despite many losses they slew the wicked Countess within Castle Templehof. Her anguished screams were said to echo throughout the halls long after the Dwarfs left runes to repel dark magic. Recently, it has become known that some of those runes have faded. And dark things stir within the castle again. Lead by a chorus of screams.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_SY1_1}Templehof
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_SY1_1}The town of Templehof has seen many nightmarish things. Formerly under the auspices of the Vampire Countess Emanuelle von Templehof the village has recently become the home to a group of Light Mages. Whilst the townsfolk cling to these people as saviours they still whisper of a phantom. The tale of Whispering Nell is well known amongst the townsfolk. A foul spectre who haunts the town and surrounding area. Stealing children and killing Men. Almost as if she owns the place.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_SY1_2}Vanhaldenhof
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_SY1_2}Vanhaldenhof is a miserable blot on the map of Sylvania. Originally constructed to guard the castle of Vanhaldenschlosse and it's master, the Necromancer Frederick van Hal. After that castle fell into ruin the village remained as an area for the vampires of Sylvania to feed on it's inhabitants and torment them. The villagers treated as little more than free roaming cattle.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_SY2}Waldenhof
Settlement.text: {=!}According to many Vampire Counts, Waldenhof is the true seat of power for Sylvania. It is where many of the Vampires dwell. And where Vlad kept his seat of power. But times change. Manfred resides in Drakenhof. Waldenhof whilst still important and thick with undead is lesser compared to Drakenhof. The town is covered in a persistent, soupy gloom. A miserable, desolate atmosphere hangs over the land. And all mortals inside the town simply live day to day. Waiting for death.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_SY2_1}Mikalsdorf
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_SY2_1}Yet another blighted and miserable place. The villagers treated as little more than snacks from nearby Von Carsteins. Though rebellion has fermented in Mikalsdorf it has been put down so many times that the villagers are wretched, sad things. Shuffling around with no hope for any rescue.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_SY2_2}Hundam
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_SY2_2}Though unassuming at first, Hundham is a place of whispered rumours. It is said that the dead walk freely on it’s streets. As if mimicking the appearance of life. Others say puppets dance the night away, stringless and alive somehow. No one knows for sure for few have braved it’s narrow streets, it’s dusty shops, or it’s surprisingly open and inviting tavern. But all who go near have warned others to never approach Hundham in the night. For that is when bands of Vampires emerge to dance and make merry. And they’d just love to have a flushed and oh so juicy mortal to dance with.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_SY2_3}Eschen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_SY1_3}When Sylvannia first fell to the Vampire Counts, the residents of Eschen built tall walls around their village. Digging in and fortifying against the cursed undead battering against their walls. Though they survived for a time, the Darkness is patient while flesh rots away. Eventually Eschen was overrun, it’s walls still standing but it’s people made to serve their new masters in death. Now the tall and impregnable walls of Eschen protect the vampires residing inside it.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_SY2_4}Stephansdorp
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_SY1_4}Stephansdorp’s claim to fame is being the final resting place of an ancient vampire. Slain by the villagers long before Sylvania was covered in darkness. It is said that several vampires have tried to resurrect this mysterious vampire. Who’s name has been lost to mortal minds for many centuries, was said to possess great treasures now locked in his hidden tomb. Adventurers and dark forces alike have searched for this tomb to no avail.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_SY2}Fort Oberstyre
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_SY2}Fort Oberstyre was once a small but mighty fortress of the Empire. Built shortly after the defeat of Vlad von Carstein in the siege of Altdorf during one of the great Vampire wars of 2010 IC. However, many centuries later after neglect and lack of manpower the fortress was easily taken by Konrad von Carstein. Though the Empire reclaimed the fort it was taken again many years later by Mannfred von Carstein. Who put a terrible curse on the fort. Whenever it is sieged the wrathful specters of past wars rise to kill any and all who threaten the fort. Those spirits lay claim to the fort. And the Empire has been unsuccessful at reclaiming it since.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_ST2_1}Murieste
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_SY2_1}The oddest thing about Murieste is that it’s people do not follow the religion of Sigmar. Nor any other state approved religion. In fact, the lowly villagers of Murieste worship the vampires around them as gods. Coverting their dark power and hoping to become one of their dark kin. The Vampires in the area tolerate this. Seeing the pathetic peasants as amusing cattle. Vampires do love to play with their food.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_SY3}Fort Bracher
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_SY3}Known for being a favourite haunt of Vampires looking to drag their victims off for a good torture session, the screams heard from Fort Bracher can be heard for miles around. Bracher is often fought over by Vampire counts. All of them looking for a new lair from which to torment Men of the Empire.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_SY3_1}Stoodhof
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_SY3_1}Most Vampire Counts leave Stoodhof alone, It has been ruled efficiently as a slaughterhouse for human cattle by it’s ruler. From the outside it simply looks like another mud covered village in the middle of this desolate land. From which very little is known about.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_SY4}Nachtschlosse Castle
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_SY4}Renowned for it’s tapestries made of human flesh. Nachtschlosse is a place of wanton butchery and desolation. With darkness around every corner and in every hall of it’s cursed interior. Monsters freely roam the corridors. Looking for new victims to try their latest stitching patterns on.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_SY4_1}Gallhof
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_SY4_1}Gallhof is often a favourite haunt of Brettonian Blood Knights. Used as a training camp and feasting hall for these bloodthirsty creatures.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_SY5}Castle Senkhof
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_SY5}Senkhof is one of the last bastions of free humans in Sylvannia. Despite officially being under the dominion of the Vampire Counts, human adventurers and crusaders often use Senkhof and it’s surrounding town to stage conflicts against their vampiric masters. Or at least as a base from which to look for treasure.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_SY5_1}Senkhof
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_SY5_1}Senkhof is one of the last bastions of free humans in Sylvannia. Despite officially being under the dominion of the Vampire Counts, human adventurers and crusaders often use Senkhof and it’s surrounding town to stage conflicts against their vampiric masters. Or at least as a base from which to look for treasure.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_SY6}Castle Wartenhof
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_SY6}Mere months before the Vampire wars. A sorcerer of Nurgle cursed the surrounding village with a plague. The nobility of Wartenhof barricaded themselves in the castle. The villagers begged for salvation as their flesh swelled and burst from deadly boils. But the nobility cared little for them. Inside the castle, the nobles slowly went insane. Becoming cultists of Nurgle within their isolated walls. They were slain by the Vampires as they took over Sylvannia. But the scars of Nurgle’s rot still remain.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_SY6_1}Wartenhof
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_SY6_1}As the nobles of Wartenhof locked themselves away, the blighted souls of Wartenhof village slowly succumbed to the sickness of Nurgle’s Rot. Many simply died. They were lucky. For Nurgle sees his sickness as a blessing and gift. And one must be alive to experience it all. When the Vampire Counts came for Wartenhof, the few villages left gladly bound themselves to vampiric service in exchange for a cure. As their service wavers the rot returns. So the Villagers do their best to remain loyal.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_SY6_2}Sumpfdorf
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_SY6_2}This swampy village is isolated from most of Sylvannia. Crossable only by boat, the houses are on stilts and it is very hard for any vampire to find purchase within Sumpdorf. The villagers and farmers know they are safe from the zombies that haunt the Dark Moor. But the local Vampire Counts still come by air from Wartenhof Castle to collect the blood tax.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_WI1}Nuln
Settlement.text: {=!}Nuln is the greatest industrial city of the Empire, producing the vast majority of the gunpowder weapons and artillery pieces used by the military, as well as the arms and armaments of the Imperial armies. Nuln is a centre for trade, as the trade from Southern Wissenland and Solland, Averland, as well as trade that comes through Blackfire pass or the Grey and Black Mountains must first pass through Nuln before reaching the rest of the Empire.. Nuln has served as the capital of the Empire for long periods of time and has historically received the support needed to truly become a metropolis. It is also the religious capital in the south for the Sigmarite Church, overseeing Wissenland, Stirland and Averland. The Elector-Countess of all of Wissenland makes her court here, while the provincial capitol remains in Wissenberg, she much prefers the comfort of Nuln to the ‘Po-faced Boughers’ of the Assembly of Wissenland.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_WI2}Pfeildorf
Settlement.text: {=!}Pfeildorf, meaning 'arrow town' in Menogothic Reikspiel is the former capital of the destroyed Grand Province of Solland. The city has had a long and troubled history, and as such a visitor can feel the burden of time on the shoulders of its inhabitants. Once Pfeildorf was as grand a city as Wissenburg and Solland as rich a province as Averland or Stirland. After an Orc invasion in the early 18th century killed off most of the nobility and sent the majority of its population into flight, Pfeildorf and the former province was informally split between Wissenland and Averland. Emperor Magnus the Pious in the 24th century attempted to restore Solland, defining its borders with Averland and Wissenland and reconstituting it as the Grand Barony of Solland. However, Solland still remains heavily intertwined with Wissenland and despite several legal agreements is in reality a part of Wissenland. Today Pfeildorf is the centre for the Sudenland wool trade, founded along the waters where the upper Reik and the River Soll meet enables the city to be a natural place for local wool and dwarf trade from the southern grey mountains to be loaded onto ships destined for Nuln and farther.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_WI3}Kreutzhofen
Settlement.text: {=!}Kreutzhofen is a small town that lies on the crossroads of three major routes of travel. To the west heading into Bretonnia is the Montdidier Pass, to the East is the Winter’s Teeth Pass, which leads through the mountains and down into the central Border Princes. Heading southwest under the Vaults is the Alimento Tunnel; a three hundred mile long underground waterway that connects Kreutzhofen with the Miraglianese town of Campogrotta, and serves as the source for both the River Soll in Wissenland and the River Cristallo in Tilea. Kreutzhofen is a quaint town and a wealthy one thanks to the flow of trade. The town’s ruler is Count Bruno Pfeifraucher, the latest Pfeifrauchers in a long line of them to have ruled over Kreutzhofen.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_WI4}Meissen
Settlement.text: {=!}Meissen is a small but incredibly wealthy town situated in Old Solland, at the end of the Granite pass and on the shores of the river Soll. Meissen is famous for its silverware including goblets, tableware and jewellery. Thanks to its ties to Karak Norn, the city has a near unlimited supply of silver ore and some of the best Silversmiths in the southern empire and many Grey Mountain Craft-Dwarfs are found here. Its river port is the largest port on the length of the river Soll, and it serves as the focal point of all trade heading north from a large region south of the city. As a result, the Silversmiths’ Guild here is extremely wealthy and influential. The Guild does most of their business out of the dwarf constructed and fortified Guildhaus, which is said to be where the guild stores most of its silver ingots for later use by its members. Meissenburger silverwork is notable enough that occasionally the town plays host to Elector-Countess Emmanuelle von Liebwitz, who never fails to purchase the best of what is on offer at the time.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_WI5}Geschburg
Settlement.text: {=!}Geschburg is a small town on the banks of the River Soll. The Toppenheimer family maintains a garrison here, as its central location in Wissenland and the presence of the ferry across the Soll makes it an important site to hold in the region. Nearby lies the site of Old Solland’s defeat, for it was in the hills east of Geschburg that eight hundred years ago an invading Orc Warboss put the Elector-Count of Solland and most of his immediate family to the sword.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_WI6}Erbshauen
Settlement.text: {=!}The small town of Erbshauen was established by Wissenlanders after the fall of Old Solland, or Sudenland as the people of Erbshauen call it. The lands outside the town are tilled for crops and are irrigated by the River Oggel. While not in the Oggelland, Erbshauen participates in fairly extensive trade with the communities there.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_WI1}Wusterburg
Settlement.text: Within sight of the Black Mountains, where the waters of the Soll, Sonne, Aulen and Hornberg meet, is the town of Wusterburg. Wursterburg caters to the many Black Dwarfs from Karak Hirn that pass through, on their way to Nuln and further. Wursterburg actually possesses a rather large community of Black and Imperial Dwarfs, This may be in part due to the site of the famous Bugman’s Brewery which sits just outside of Wusterburg. While this famous beer company was destroyed by a goblin horde, its memory goes on in the minds of those who can remember its taste. Wursterburg mourns this disgrace to the art of Brewery, yet the town remains important as a centre of trade and as one of the only ferries across the River Soll. Baron Manfred von Eigenhof is the ruler of Wusterburg, and is known to be decently wealthy by nobleman’s standards thanks to the flow of trade.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_WI2}Nehren
Settlement.text: Nehren is a small fort established to guard the upper River Soll and the fertile pasture lands near the Wild Pass leading into the forest of Athel Loren.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_WI3}Sonnefurt
Settlement.text: Sonnefurt lies at the point where the River Sonne meets the River Soll. The castle here was built at some point after Magnus the Pious attempted to restore Old Solland, since then it has served as an invaluable defensive point to guard against Greenskins entering the Empire from the Icy Wind or Winter’s Teeth Passes.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_WI4}Mendelhof
Settlement.text: Mendelhof used to be a small Sollander village in the Oggelland, today a fort stands in place of the former settlement. Built on the east shores of the River Oggel, the fort was constructed in order to watch over the Oggelland Pass as well as the disputed land between Wissenland and Averland, which lies between the Oggel and the upper River Reik.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_WI5}Kolbhugel
Settlement.text: Kolbhugel was established a stopover between Wusterburg and Waldbach, eventually a former Elector-Count of Wissenland saw fit to establish a permanent garrison here, both to help combat highwaymen and to use the site to send reinforcements to either Mendelhof to Sonnefurt should they require assistance.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_WI6}Staig
Settlement.text: Staig is a small fort established to watch over the upper Reik. Over the years the garrison here has stopped many goblin river pirates from travelling deeper into the empire.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_WI1_1}Grissenwald
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_WI1_1}Grissenwald is the northernmost settlement in Wissenland, right along the banks of the Reik. South of the beginning of the Vorbergland Canal System as well as the southern extent of the Reikwald forest. The Dwarf Shanty, ‘Kazid Slumbol’ sits against the south side of its palisade, and is mostly home to transient Dwarf traders and caravanners, resting here with their more permanent kin before continuing on their routes. Many hunters, trappers and woodcutters make their residence here and during the day will go north into the Reikwald to make their living. The Southern Reikwald is known for being particularly infested with monsters and ne'er do wells. As a result the ruler of Grissenwald, Count Bruno Pfeifraucher, is a professional military man who is often seen leading a patrol around his town to keep the forest’s dangers at bay.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_WI1_2}Rohrhausen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_WI1_2}Rohrhausen is an isolated Wissenlander village known for its excellent vineyards, popular even in some of the best taverns in Nuln. This is in part thanks to the cool waters of the River Griss, which come out of the mountains near Rohrhausen.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_WI1_3}Wissenburg
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_WI1_3}Wissenburg is the capital of Wissenland and, while it might not carry the economic or cultural weight of Nuln, it is truly the centre of the people. The folk here are the epitome of those virtues which makes Wissenlanders unique from the rest of the Empire. The boughers, artisans and labourers go about their business with thrift and daur pragmatism, speaking clearly and in short direct sentences. Unlike in Altdorf or Nuln, the people here have no time for poetic or flowery expressions. Most of the citizens work the various temples in the city into their daily routine, picking one each day and paying their respect if only for a few minutes, allowing them to pay respect to most of the principal gods each week. Wissenburg is also the last stop for river trade on the upper Reik before Nuln and is surrounded by good farmland. Elector-Countess Emmanuelle von Liebwitz seldom journeys to Wissenburg, coming only to meet the ‘po-faced boughers’ which sit on the Assembly of Wissenland. As a result, while the town is ruled in her name, Baroness Toppenheimer has been given more and more control over the province as a whole.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_WI1_2}Dotternbach
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_WI1_4}On the Border of the Grey Mountains, along the shores of the River Wissen is the village of Dotternbach. The Wissenlanders here are shepherds used to climbing high into the lands west of their homes, and as such make strong recruits when they have the young men to spare.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_WI2_1}Halgerbach
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_WI2_1}Halgerbach is an isolated Wissenlander village right on the traditional border with Old Solland. It sits on the shores of the River Wissen, which the people here use to irrigate their crops.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_WI2_2}Durbheim
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_WI2_2}On the western shore of the River Soll, at one of the only nearby ferries across the river, is the village of Durbheim. The Sollanders here tend sheep to provide wool to nearby Pfeildorf.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_WI2_3}Bernau
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_WI2_3}Bernau is your typical Sollander village; the people here are mostly shepherds who raise sheep for their wool. They sell this wool at nearby Pfeildorf for a decent price and are happy with their modest living.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_WI2_4}Sexau
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_WI2_4}On the eastern shore of the River Soll is the Sollander village of Sexau. The people here are not very well off, and typically can only grow enough food to feed themselves. What extra they do produce is taken to market at Pfeildorf.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_WI3_1}Weilerberg
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_WI3_1}Across the River Soll from Kreutzhofen is the small village of Weilerberg. The closeness of the two communities results in a great many ties between them. For instance the town grave digger for Kreutzhofen, Boris Hippler, makes his residence here in Weilerberg.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_WI3_2}Serrig
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_WI3_2}The Sollanders of Serrig are simple people and are proud of it. Asking any of the shepherds here if they have any greater aspirations than sheep will elicit a round of laughter followed by the statement that: ‘my family has been here since the fall of Solland, not even a Daemon could make me abandon our trade!’

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_WI4_1}Owingen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_WI4_1}Owingen is a small Wissenlander farming community on the shore of the lower River Soll, just south of a small marshy confluence caused by the lower Soll meeting with the Soll. The people here sell much of their grain to nearby Karak Norn in return for coin and drink, though they will sell you what grain they have to spare.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_WI4_2}Heisenberg
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_WI4_2}Heisenberg is well renowned for its deep red wines, which are shipped and sold from Pfeildorf to Kislev. The Wissenlander winemakers here credit the upper River Soll for irrigating their land, as well as the fair winds out of the Granite pass, for the quality of their fruit.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_WI4_3}Augen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_WI4_3}Along the shore of the lower River Soll is the village of Augen. At one time this land would have been populated by Sollanders, but today this part of Sudenland is home to Wissenlanders. The people here can trace their roots back at least three centuries and are very experienced farmers. Augen is well used by passersby, as the village sits on the Granite Pass road, the main route between Meissen and Karak Norn.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_WI4_4}Kelgard
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_WI4_4}Kelgard is a small Wissenlander village on the western shore of the upper Soll. The people here mostly mine the nearby mountains for Iron ore.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_WI5_1}Fluorn
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_WI5_1}To the north of Geschburg is Fluorn, an old Sollander village that has been on the maps since before the fall of Solland. The people here carry on the traditions of Solland, and even have a small shrine to Myrmidia.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_WI5_2}Althausen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_WI5_2}To the south of Geschburg is Althausen, a Sollander village populated mostly by shepherds. The land here is also good for vineyards, and while the Althausen vintage hasn’t become renowned outside of the region, it is well received in Geschburg.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_WI5_3}Sochtenau
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_WI5_3}Sochtenau is a relatively new community, established within the last few generations as an attempt by the people of Solland to restore some of their former glory. Like many Sollanders, they seem to carry the weight of their past on their backs and in their bones, but they take pride in their work and look after their sheep with thrift and efficiency.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_WI6_1}Steingart
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_WI6_1}Steingart was once a moderately sized city. With the destruction of old Solland, what remains of Steingart today is but a husk of what used to be. Around the present day town can be found the eight hundred year old ruins. In Steingart, the oppressive air that hangs around the Sollanders is the heaviest, as if they’d be happier if they could just forget their former grandeur. To the south of Steingart is a set of ancient standing stones, commonly called ‘Taal’s Fangs.’ This name is in spite of the insistence of the cult of Taal that the site is not Taalite in origin. A ferry across the River Oggel is here, in the direction of Mendelhof.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_WI6_2}Moasach
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_WI6_2}Near Waldbach is the small Wissenlander settlement of Moasach. The people of Moasach provide for themselves by raising pigs.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_WI6_3}Ballenhof
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_WI6_3}Within sight of the wall in Agbeiten is the Wissenlander village of Ballenhof. The people here are friendly, but have a deep mistrust of Averlanders, saying: ‘they refuse to ev’r sign a contract, take me at my word they say, on their ‘oner they say. I tell em if I’m to take em on their ‘oner, then I need the Crowns and Shillings now!’

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_WI1_1}Eigenhof
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_WI1_1}Irrigated by the River Soll, the Sollanders here at Eigenhof are able to grow a large quantity of grain and other foodstuffs, which they often take to Wursterburg to be loaded onto a ship and sold farther north.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_WI1_2}Rotenbach
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_WI1_2}Nestled in the hills to the northwest of Wusterburg is the Sollander village of Rötenbach. The people here are mostly shepherds, and have been known to range their sheep as far as Serrig.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_WI2_1}Salmfahre
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_WI2_1}Salmfahre is a small Wissenlander farming community along the shores of the upper River Soll. It is protected from danger by nearby Nehren.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_WI2_2}Trulben
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_WI2_2}Trulben is a small Sollander village that primarily gets by through the wool trade. The shepherds here often work with the shepherds of Rotenbach and Serrig.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_WI3_1}Scharmbeck
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_WI3_1}Near the mountainous source of the River Sonne is the village of Scharmbeck. The people here are hardy mountain dwelling Sollanders, who make their living either by working in the mine at nearby Tierhügel or by raising cattle in the small plain to the northwest of the settlement. On the rise just north of the village centre is a ring of ancient standing stones.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_WI3_2}Thalfang
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_WI3_2}On the Sonnefurt-Wursterburg road is the village of Thalfang, which cuts timber and entertains passerbys.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_WI4_1}Merfeld
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_WI4_1}Merfeld is a village in the Oggelland and as a result is part of the land held in dispute between Averland and Wissenland. To the north of Merfeld is the bridge over the upper Reik to Hocheleben, to the south is the village of Jengen.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_WI4_2}Jengen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_WI4_2}Jengen is a small community in the Oggelland that in recent years has found itself in the middle of a dispute between Wissenland and Averland. By an ancient treaty the division between Wissenland and Averland is set south of the upper River Reik and fifty leagues east of the River Oggel. Unfortunately, the upper Reik is known to change its course regularly and leagues are no longer used in the Empire in favour of the Imperial Mile. The fertile, well watered grasslands of the Oggeland is greatly desired by both the Wissenland Sheep Herders, and the Averland Cattle Ranchers; brawls or even ‘battles’ have been known to commence between the two groups. Rancher and Herder alike have petitioned their lords to settle this dispute, with the sword if need be.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_WI4_1}Osterzell
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_WI4_3}Osterzell is formerly recognized as part of Wissenland, the fort at Mendelhof is there to insure this. Despite these legal realities, the people of Osterzell have always maintained a greater kinship with Averlanders than they have with Wissenlanders or even Sollanders. Should Averland choose to act on the Oggelland dispute, the people of Osterzell would support them.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_WI5_1}Pahl
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_WI5_1}Pahl is a Sollander village. The people here are mostly shepherds and rely on the production of wool to make ends meet.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_WI5_2}Kroppenleben
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_WI5_2}Travellers heading by the Icy Wind Pass to or from Karak Hirn inevitably pass through Kroppenleben. Many choose to stop here and spend the night before continuing their journey. The small community of Kroppenleben has no qualms with providing these travellers with shelter, or selling them the furs that local hunters have collected this season. Kroppenleben is on the shores of the River Hornberg, just after the River Aulen has contributed to its flow.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_WI5_3}Bedernau
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_WI5_3}Bedernau is a Sollander village just north across the Soll from Wusterburg. The people here produce just enough food to feed themselves, taking what little they have to spare to market at Wusterburg.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_WI6_1}Pforzen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_WI6_1}Pforzen is a small community of Wissenlander foresters, who provide wood for many of the nearby settlements.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_WI6_2}Mauchen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_WI6_2}Mauchen is a small community of Wissenlander foresters, they are known particularly well in Wuppertal, where most of their wood is shipped across the Reik for cutting.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_WI6_3}Ellwangen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_WI6_3}On the road to Staig and Wissenburg from Erbshauen is the small fishing village of Ellwangen, whose name comes from an ancient legal requirement for road construction.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_TB1}Talabheim
Settlement.text: {=!}Talabheim, known in ancient times as Taalheim, which means Taal's Victory, is the capital city of the Grand Duchy of Talabecland. Talabheim lies deep within the Great Forest of the Empire, and as such earned its name as the Eye of the Forest, like the eye of a mighty storm, the crater being an island of calm amidst the surrounding danger. The city itself is built within a huge shallow crater called the Taalbaston, which is many miles across, whose outer edge formed a large rocky rim and a natural wall. This wall has been built up and fortified with many tall gun towers and effectively marks the boundary of the city itself. The land inside is extensive and includes fertile farmlands, a lake filled with fresh water as well as the grand city itself, ensuring that should a mighty enemy be able to breach through Talabecland's armies, so long as the enemy is held back by the great crater walls, the city and its proud people can withstand the onslaught of siege almost indefinitely. The River Talabec flows around the outside of the crater, and where it flows past the north-eastern edge of the wall, there is a fortified Imperial town known as Taalagrad and a deep harbour from which lies the river fleets. The largest of Talabheim’s temples is dedicated to Taal and to a lesser extent Rhya. Even though the primary place of Taal’s worship continues to be the Sacred Forest, worshippers who live within the confines of the city value an opportunity to seek spiritual enlightenment without making a trip to the other end of the crater.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_TB1_1}Talagraad
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_TB1_1}A run-down pest hole inhabited by the poorest of the poor, alcoholism and crime are rampant here. The population has around 1200 kislevite immigrants who live in their own slice of heaven called little kislev. The kislevites and the local talabeclanders don’t really interact much.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_TB1_2}Teupitz
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_TB1_2}Upstream of the river Uckro, The villagers of Teupitz are a tight knit community, where everyone adds to the needs of each other. They don’t get many visitors and those that do visit often come to trade for wood from the local lumber mill.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_TB1_3}Dreetz
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_TB1_3}Close to the treeline of the forest that touches talabheim’s crater wall. The villagers of Dreetz keep cows, many shepherds and some veterinarians take care of the great herd of cattle that graze in and around the fields of Dreetz.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_TB1_4}Lochrafurt
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_TB1_4}Near the mouth of the river Lochra, hence the name, the villagers of Lochrafurt are farmers and pig herders. Water is often carried through the village from the river to provide for the fields and the many pigs that bathe in the mud pits around the village.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_TB2}Bek
Settlement.text: {=!}Chief town of the province ruled by Count Josef von Behring, Bek is normally a quiet trading town that exports lumber from the Great Forest and dried fish, and collects tolls for the use of its quays. Since the war began, the town and surrounding area has been flooded with over a thousand immigrants from Ostland, so many that they outnumber the townsfolk themselves. This has greatly strained resources and fights between locals and refugees are common and increasing in size. Count von Behring was an early supporter of Elector Count Feuerbach, and now he expects help in return. Feuerbach has sent a troop of his personal guard to Bek to maintain order, but rumours say that there will soon be a larger force arriving with instructions to invade Ostland “to restore order and allow the refugees to return home.” Order under whose rule is the open question.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_TB2_1}Viernau
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_TB2_1}A fishing village that borders the river Talabec. Vienau is surrounded by tents that bear the colours of Ostland. However the village of Vienau doesn’t give the ostlanders the treatment that Bek gives them. Even though they outnumber the locals, the village elder has put the immigrants to work, either aiding in the fishing, forming hunter groups, with the local priest’s blessing of course, or farmers.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_TB2_2}Freital
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_TB2_2}A small village with a stretch of the great forest to the east and a few hills to the south. Its villagers are mainly woodcutters and eke out a decent existence trading said timber.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_TB2_3}Ertburg
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_TB2_3}Bordering the river Lochra on two sides, Ertburg enjoys the natural protection the river offers from the west and the south. Ertburg is a diverse village, with some hunters, some farmers, some fishermen and a few priests who tend to a small chapel of Taal.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_TB3}Krugenheim
Settlement.text: {=!}Along the river stir lies Krugenheim, a town that has bred many decent generals of the empire here today. The peasantry of Krugenheim provide the town with fish and crops while the barracks house many regiments of well trained state troops.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_TB3_1}Gersdorf
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_TB3_1}A bustling town along the river Stir and the river kölpin with many of the local populace consisting of woodcutters. There’s alot of taverns for the woodcutters to take a load off after work and all of them are named after the job their patrons have. They have Mourner’s guild, which is dedicated to the Cult of Morr, and is responsible for organising funerals and seeing to the upkeep of the local graveyard.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_TB3_2}Sabritz
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_TB3_2}An unassuming farming village east of the river kölpin, no road leads to Sabritz, instead farmers follow the river south to reach Gersdorf. They don’t care much about this, for they prefer solitude and are quite suspicious of strangers.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_TB4}Volgen
Settlement.text: {=!}A moderately wealthy town south of the river Talabec, its villages don’t suffer too much from poverty and it collects healthy taxes from them. Its inhabitants are well fed and work hard to keep it that way.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_TB4_1}Priestlicheim
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_TB4_1}Separated from the Barren Hills by a stretch of the Great Forest, Priestlicheim is home to a large Sigmarite monastery, the Temple of Leopold “the Hammer of Faith.” The brothers here are dedicated to the study and eventual eradication of whatever curses the Barren Hills. Although they will explore the hills themselves, they also hire adventurers if other matters demand their attention. The monastery also hunts down any Mutants that wander north out of the hills.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_TB4_2}Garndorf
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_TB4_2}Garndorf is a fortified village with its back to the river Talabec and one side bordering the River Karwe. Garndorf enjoys its natural protection, its land borders protected by a stone wall, Garndorf has a solid strategic position. One can enter Garndorf through a portcullis in the wall or through a ferry across the river Talabec.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_TB4_3}Guttow
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_TB4_3}The southernmost village of Volgen. Its villagers maintain a big herd of sheep that graze near the barren hills. Despite Priestlicheim’s efforts to stop the supposed hauntings from the barren hills, the odd sheep still goes missing now and again. Despite this the herd remains quite large.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_TB1}Gostahof
Settlement.text: {=!}Between the River Stir and a part of the Great forest lies the minor fortification of Gostahof. Gostahof processes most of the timber that gets chopped from the great forest and that comes in from the east due to its fancy watermill of dwarfen make.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_TB1_1}Missen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_TB2_1}Bordering the river Stir and being at the centre of a crossroads, Missen sees alot of traffic from the surrounding villages. Missen has bits of forest a few ways away and the local populace earns a decent living trading timber.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_TB1_2}Sydow
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_TB1_2}A community of tree lovers as they’re often described, they give praise to Taal and only use the wood of dead trees, they get by on their meagre farms and foraging in the great forest.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_TB2}Hermsdorf
Settlement.text: {=!}The southernmost settlement on the Old Forest Road is a small logging town with nearly 400 inhabitants. Hermsdorf is built near the crest of a low hill, overlooking the Wurtbad valley that extends 15 miles to the south. The local ruler, Baron Waldemar von Züten, spends most of his time carousing in Wurtbad and leaves routine administrative duties to his bailiff. Hermsdorf is situated at the junction of two major roads along the River Stir and receives a great deal of traffic.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_TB2_1}Radische
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_TB2_1}A village deep in the great forest. A dirt road leads to Radische from Hermsdorf. Despite having made a decent copper trading timber in the old days but out of respect for the woods the inhabitants of Radische have now changed their craft to equestrianism.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_TB2_2}Ossino
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_TB2_2}A long way from other towns and villages the village of Ossino is quite poor, despite its decent food stocks. It sees a decent amount of traffic from anyone that comes and goes from Ostermark and sometimes people that travel down the river Stir, but not many wish to stay long in such a desolate looking place. Many requests have been sent to Hermsdorf for tools and supplies to fix the village but not much has been set in motion as of yet.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_TB3}Obelheim
Settlement.text: {=!}One of the few stops along the Old Forest Road, Obelhem relies on its surrounding villages to provide it food. Most of the imported wheat and barley gets turned into beer for its inn.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_TB3_1}Badau
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_TB3_1}A village close to a small bit of forest and surrounded by small hills. The villagers of Badau have many farms close to the base of the hills to utilize rainwater flowing down the hills for irrigation.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_TB3_2}Horno
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_TB3_2}Bordering a great swathe of the great forest the villagers of Horno are mainly hunters and woodsmen. Horno earns a decent amount of money from the meat and hides they sell and give praise to taal for it.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_TB4}Ravenstein
Settlement.text: {=!}Castle Ravenstein stands a proud vigil looking over its northern neighbours. Surrounded by the river Talabec and the River Lug the Castle is well defended. Combined with its walls it is indeed a tough place to siege. Its inhabitants work hard to provide food for the castle.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_TB4_1}Klepzig
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_TB4_1}Slightly wealthier in terms of food and coin than most villages in Talabecland. Klepzig enjoys the protection Castle Ravenstein provides.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_TB4_2}Zurin
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_TB4_2}Tucked in between two parts of the Great forest, Zurin houses a decent amount of Taal worshippers, often going on pilgrimage to Talabheim or answering Taal’s call. The Fishermen of Zurin often walk north towards the river Uckro to fish, enjoying the walk in the great forest as they do so. Those that remain keep themselves busy with the worship of Taal and tending the farms.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_RL1}Altdorf
Settlement.text: {=!}Altdorf is at once perhaps the greatest city of the Empire and perhaps the entire known world, only rivaled in its size and importance by the likes of Marienburg, Nuln and Erengrad. Emperor Karl Franz rules both the Grand Principality of the Reikland and the Empire of Sigmar from this sprawling city, and what better a capital than the city founded by Sigmar himself two and a half millennia ago? Besides for its history, Altdorf is geographically the focal point of trade for three quarters of the Empire; for here all of the goods and travel from the states of Ostermark, Talabecland, Hochland, Stirland, Wissenland and Averland must go before they can move down the Reik to Marienburg and beyond. The city also hosts numerous knightly orders, the center of the Sigmarite church and the eight Imperial colleges of magic. Despite this prosperity and importance, Altdorf is a restless city: overpopulated and ripe for political violence, much of the fair city and its services have been pushed to their limits.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_RL1_1}Frederheim
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_RL1_1}Frederheim is a small Reiklander village just north of Altdorf on the Altdorf-Middenheim road. While the town is a possession of Karl-Franz and is a part of Altdorf’s demesne, the Emperor has seen fit to give oversight of it in all but name to the Cult of Shallya. This is a result of the cult's request for an area in which to establish a walled hospice and sanatorium.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_RL1_2}Kaldach
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_RL1_2}On the eastern side of the confluence of the rivers Taal and Reik sits the village of Kaldach. The town is notable particularly for being the demarcation of the Reikland/Talabecland border. Besides this, it remains a small farming community.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_RL1_3}Hochloff
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_RL1_3}Directly west of Altdorf, between the river Reik and the Weissbruck canal is the village of Hochloff. The town is known for the type of grain it raises the Hochloffkorn which is very well regarded for making a high quality flour.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_RL2}Schilderheim
Settlement.text: {=!}At the Confluence of the River Reik and the River Schilder sits the town of Schilderheim. Ruled by Graf Robert von Uhland, Schilderheim is an important river market down river from altdorf, being one of the last places that trade on the River Reik can stop before reaching Marienburg.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_RL2_1}Holthusen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_RL2_1}Holthusen is a town in western Reikland on the river Schilder. By road it lies between Eilhart and Schilderheim.
